result.description:

Input: 

13
Result: 
true
Input: 
false

false
Input: 
"abc"
Result: 
true
Input: 
"0"
Result: 
false

Note: For Integer and Double values which are not 0, the transform returns true.
For strings that are not empty or not "0‚Äù, the transform returns true.
For Complex objects and arrays that have a value, the transform returns true.
For true boolean values, the transform returns true.

result.description:
Converts the input Date/Time, Date, or Due Date to a String.

Input:

  • Date/Time, Date, or Due Date

If the input is a Date or Due Date, the transform creates a full date/time value using time values of hour 0, minute 0, and second 0.

Parameters:

  • Output Date Format - Date/time or date format of the output String.
  • Custom Format - Valid date/time or date format represented as a String. Required only if Custom Format is selected as the Date Format.

Output:

  • String formatted as specified in Output Date Format

Example:

Input: 

1996-01-16 19:56:10
Output Date Format: 
MM/dd/yy
Result: 
"01/16/96"

Example:

Input: 

1969-12-31 14:23:57
Output Date Format: 
Custom (enter below)
Custom Format: 
'On' MMM dd, yyyy 'at' hh:mm a
Result: 
"On Dec 31, 1969 at 2:23 PM"

Note: Runtime Date/Time values are not localized and appear in the UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) time zone.

Note: If input data type is not Date/Time, Date, or Due Date, the data is not transformed at runtime.

Common Date Formats
Format Example
Year y 1970, 1971, ... 2004, 2005
Month MM 01, 02, ... 11, 12
Month Name MMM Jan, Feb, ... Nov, Dec
Day in Month dd 01, 02, ... 30, 31
Day Name EEE Sun, Mon, ... Fri, Sat
Hour (12-hour) h 1, 2, ... 11, 12
Hour (24-hour) HH 00, 01, ... 22, 23
Minute in Hour mm 00, 01, ... 58, 59
Second in Minute ss 00, 01, ... 58, 59
Escape Character
(Single Quote)		 ' 'at' h:mm a = at 1:30 PM

Read More.
result.label: Date to String
result.name: date_to_string

result.description:
Returns a String with escaped special characters or injected values for SQL identifiers (such as table, view, and column names). Wraps the input String in database-specific quotes.

Input:

  • String

Parameters:

  • Database - The database-specific context in which characters are escaped

Output:

  • Escaped String - SQL identifiers properly escaped based on selected Database

Example:

Input: 

"simple_column"
Result (using MySQL Database): 
"`simple_column`"

Note: Don't enclose the input data pill in quotes. The system automatically wraps the input value with the type of quotes or backticks that apply to your database type. If your input String contains a period character, Sanitize SQL Identifier returns an error. To join SQL identifiers using a period, use two data pills concatenated with a period and apply Sanitize SQL Identifier to both pills. If input data type is not String, the data is not transformed at runtime.

Read More.
result.label: Sanitize SQL Identifier
result.name: sanitize_sql_identifier

result.description:
Subtracts days, hours, minutes, and/or seconds from the input Date/Time, Date, or Due Date.

Input:

  • Date/Time, Date, or Due Date

If the input is a Date or Due Date, the transform creates a full date/time value using time values of hour 0, minute 0, and second 0.

Parameters:

  • Duration - Amount of time to subtract in days, hours, minutes, and seconds

Output:

  • Date/Time - Transformed Date/Time after subtracting the specified Duration

Example:

Input: 

2019-09-12 11:00:00
Duration (2 Days, 1 Hour, 5 Minutes, 10 seconds): 
1970-01-03 01:05:10
Result: 
2019-09-10 09:54:50

Note: If input data type is not Date/Time, Date, or Due Date, the data is not transformed at runtime.

Read More.
result.label: Subtract Time
result.tags: date, time, datetime, hours, minutes, seconds
result.name: subtract_time

\"

Output:

""'Georgi'' OR ''1''=''1'""

  • End Index - Index of the last character to include in the returned substring

Input: 

"Example input string."
Start Index: 
3
End Index: 
6

Output:

Input:

[7, 2, 3, 1, 7, 9]

Result:

[1, 2, 3, 7, 7, 9]

Note: If input data type is not an array.string, array.integer, array.boolean or array.datetime, the data is not transformed at runtime.

Note: array.object type input is not supported. Sort is case sensitive for array.strings

Read More.
result.label: Sort
result.name: sort

result.description:
A mathematical function that approximates a numeric value based on rounding rules and a digit position. The function rounds up by adding one to the digit to be rounded and then replacing all digits to its right with zeroes.

Input:

  • Number

Parameters:

  • Number of Digits - A positive integer specifying the position of the digit to be rounded starting on the left.

Output:

  • Number - as the rounded value of the input Number.

Example:

Input: 

194
Parameter: 
2
Result: 
190

Note: The function uses the digit to the right of the parameter digit to round up or down. If the digit to the right has a value of 0 to 4, the function rounds down. If the digit to the right has a value of 5 to 9, then the function rounds up. If there is no digit to the right, then the function rounds down.

Read More.
result.label: Round
result.name: round

result.description:
Returns a String free of any unsafe command injections in your Bash shell script. Wraps the input String with single quotes and escapes any existing single quotes so that you can pass the String directly to a shell function as a safe argument.

Input:

  • String

Output:

  • Escaped String - Shell arguments are properly escaped

Example:

Input: 

"$(echo 127.0.0.1 | sleep 5)"
Result: 
"'$(echo 127.0.0.1 | sleep 5)'"

Note: If input data type is not String, the data is not transformed at runtime.

Read More.
result.label: Sanitize Bash Shell Arguments
result.name: sanitize_bash_args

result.description:
Changes the case of words in the input string. Capitalizes the first letter of each word, and makes every other letter in the word lower case. A word is considered any string separated by a space, hyphen, backslash, or forward slash character. The transform function always evaluates words from left-to-right to determine the first letter.

Input:

  • String

Output:

  • String in proper case

Example:

Input: 

"exAMPle-input string/TEXT"
Result: 
"Example-Input String/Text"

Note: If input data type is not String, the transformation is ignored.

result.description:
Returns the week of the year that a specific date falls on.

Input:

  • Date/Time

Output:

  • Integer - returns week component of the specified input.

Example:

Input:

"2021-04-07 12:01:12"

Result:

"15"

Note: Runtime Date/Time values are not localized and appear in the UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) time zone.

Note: If input data type is not Date/Time, the data is not transformed at runtime.

result.label: Week
result.name: week

result.description:
Converts the input String to a Date/Time.

Input:

  • String formatted as specified in Input Date Format

Parameters:

  • Input Date Format - Date/time or date format of the input String.
  • Custom Format - Valid date/time or date format represented as a String. Required only if Custom Format is selected as the Date Format.

Output:

  • Date/Time

If the date/time value for the Custom Format is incomplete, the transform creates a full date/time value using default dates and times. The transform defaults to the current year, the current month, day 1 of a month, hour 0, minute 0, and second 0.

Example:

Input: 

"1995-11-20"
Input Date Format: 
ISO Date (2004-06-28)
Result: 
1995-11-20 00:00:00

Example:

Input: 

"On Dec 2019 at 11:59 PM"
Input Date Format: 
"Custom (enter below)"
Custom Format: 
"'On' MMM yyyy 'at' hh:mm a"
Result: 
"2019-10-01 23:59:00"

Note: Runtime Date/Time values are not localized and appear in the UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) time zone.

Note: If input data type is not String, the data is not transformed at runtime.

Common Date Formats
Format Example
Year y 1970, 1971, ... 2004, 2005
Month MM 01, 02, ... 11, 12
Month Name MMM Jan, Feb, ... Nov, Dec
Day in Month dd 01, 02, ... 30, 31
Day Name EEE Sun, Mon, ... Fri, Sat
Hour (12-hour) h 1, 2, ... 11, 12
Hour (24-hour) HH 00, 01, ... 22, 23
Minute in Hour mm 00, 01, ... 58, 59
Second in Minute ss 00, 01, ... 58, 59
Escape Character
(Single Quote)		 ' 'at' h:mm a = at 1:30 PM

Read More.

result.name: string_to_date

result.description:
A utility function that checks whether the input value is true. The function supports Integers, Double, Boolean, Complex Objects, and String.

Input:

  • Pills or values of above mentioned Types

Output:

  • True/False

Example:

Input: 

13
Result: 
true
Input: 
false
Result: 
false
Input: 
"abc"
Result: 
true
Input: 
"0.0"
Result: 
false

Note: For Integer and Double values that are not 0, the transform returns true.
For strings that are not empty or not "0‚Äù, the transform returns true.
For Complex objects and arrays that have a value, the transform returns true.
For true boolean values, the transform returns true.

Read More.
